title: 95-Year-Old Female with Longstanding Sensorineural Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I am having difficulty hearing music when I go line dancing. Even though I use an amplified telephone, I don't get much benefit and struggle to understand speech during conversations.

problem_summary.onset: Diagnosed over 25 years ago; no hearing loss reported in childhood or young adulthood.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Significant family history (maternal grandmother, sister, two children). Denies tinnitus and dizziness.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty with music appreciation and telephone communication despite using amplification.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Improve hearing for social activities (line dancing) and telephone use.

history.present_illness: Patient is a 95-year-old female with a 25-year history of hearing loss. She currently wears 7-year-old digital BTE hearing aids with custom standard earmolds.
history.otologic_history: No report of ear pathology. Denies tinnitus or dizziness.
history.prior_management: Has used amplification for 25 years. Current devices are 7 years old.
history.patient_goals: Better understanding on the telephone and hearing music.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral, symmetrical, moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss at 250-2000 Hz (with a slight improvement at 1000 Hz), sloping to severe/profound in the high frequencies. No air-bone gaps.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores are in agreement with pure-tone averages. Word recognition scores (WRS) are very poor bilaterally, indicating significant distortion.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear function bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Could not be measured due to excessive artifact.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral, symmetrical, moderately severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss. While middle ear function is normal, speech understanding is disproportionately poor (34-40%), suggesting significant cochlear or retrocochlear distortion common in advanced presbycusis. This poor clarity explains her limited benefit from the amplified telephone.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms a significant permanent hearing loss in both ears.

The main challenge you are facing is 'clarity' rather than just volume. Even when speech is loud enough, your nerves are having trouble sending a clear signal to the brain, which is why the amplified phone isn't helping enough.
Your current hearing aids are 7 years old; newer technology may help manage background noise better, but we must be realistic about the clarity limitations.
For the telephone, I recommend trying a captioned telephone (like CapTel) so you can read what is being said while you listen.
When line dancing, position yourself where you can see the instructor or speakers best, but understand that music fidelity may be difficult to restore fully.
notes_for_actor: You are 95 years old but active (you go line dancing).
